Second-Order Guarantees in Federated Learning

Abstract

Federated learning is a useful framework for centralized learning from distributed data under practical considerations of heterogeneity, asynchrony, and privacy. Federated architectures are frequently deployed in deep learning settings, which generally give rise to non-convex optimization problems. Nevertheless, most existing analysis are either limited to convex loss functions, or only establish first-order stationarity, despite the fact that saddle-points, which are first-order stationary, are known to pose bottlenecks in deep learning. We draw on recent results on the second-order optimality of stochastic gradient algorithms in centralized and decentralized settings, and establish second-order guarantees for a class of federated learning algorithms.

1 Introduction

Federated learning pursues solutions to global optimization problems over distributed collections of agents by relying on the exchange of model updates in lieu of raw data. Federated architectures are frequently deployed in highly heterogeneous environments, where different agents have access to data of varying quality and varying computational resources. Performance guarantees for federated architectures are generally limited to convex loss functions, or to establishing limiting first-order stationarity on non-convex losses. First-order stationary points include minima, but can be saddle-points or local maxima as well. Saddle-points in particular have been identified as bottlenecks for optimization algorithms in many important applications, such as deep learning [2, 3]. It is hence desirable to devise algorithms and performance analyses that ensure efficient escape from saddle-points despite high levels of asynchrony and heterogeneity. Recent works have identified gradient perturbations as playing a key role in guaranteeing efficient saddle-points escape in centralized and fully decentralized architectures [4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10]. Here, we establish analogous results in the federated learning framework, extending recent analysis from [1] to allow for multiple local updates.

Specifically, we consider a collection of K𝐾K agents, where each agent k𝑘k is equipped with a risk loss function Jk​(w)subscript𝐽𝑘𝑤J_{k}(w), which is defined as the expectation of a loss Q​(w;\xk)𝑄𝑤subscript\x𝑘Q(w;\x_{k}):

Jk​(w)≜\E\xk​Q​(w;\xk)≜subscript𝐽𝑘𝑤subscript\Esubscript\x𝑘𝑄𝑤subscript\x𝑘J_{k}(w)\triangleq\E_{\x_{k}}Q(w;\x_{k}) (1)

Here, Q​(w;\xk)𝑄𝑤subscript\x𝑘Q(w;\x_{k}) quantifies the fit of the model parametrization w𝑤w to the random data \xksubscript\x𝑘\x_{k}. Note that we allow for the data \xksubscript\x𝑘\x_{k} to vary with the agent index k𝑘k, resulting in different risk functions Jk​(w)subscript𝐽𝑘𝑤J_{k}(w) at different agents. It is common in multi-agent settings to pursue a model wosuperscript𝑤𝑜w^{o} that performs well on average by solving:

wo≜\argminw​∑k=1Kpk​Jk​(w)≜superscript𝑤𝑜subscript\argmin𝑤superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝐽𝑘𝑤w^{o}\triangleq\argmin_{w}\sum_{k=1}^{K}p_{k}J_{k}(w) (2)

where the {pk}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑘1𝐾\{p_{k}\}_{k=1}^{K} denote non-negative weights, normalized to add up to one without loss of generality. It is common to let pk=1Ksubscript𝑝𝑘1𝐾p_{k}=\frac{1}{K}, hence giving equal weight to every agent k𝑘k. In settings where agents are heterogeneous, and exhibit varying amounts of data, or varying computational capabilities, heterogeneous weights pksubscript𝑝𝑘p_{k} can result in improved performance, which we allow for generality. Perhaps the most straightforward approach to pursuing wosuperscript𝑤𝑜w^{o} is by means of gradient descent, applied directly to (2), resulting in:

wi=wi−1−μ​∑k=1Kpk​∇Jk​(wi−1)=wi−1−μ​∇J​(wi−1)subscript𝑤𝑖subscript𝑤𝑖1𝜇superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑝𝑘∇subscript𝐽𝑘subscript𝑤𝑖1subscript𝑤𝑖1𝜇∇𝐽subscript𝑤𝑖1w_{i}=w_{i-1}-\mu\sum_{k=1}^{K}p_{k}\nabla J_{k}(w_{i-1})=w_{i-1}-\mu\nabla J(w_{i-1}) (3)

where we defined J​(⋅)≜∑k=1Kpk​Jk​(⋅)≜𝐽⋅superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝐽𝑘⋅J(\cdot)\triangleq\sum_{k=1}^{K}p_{k}J_{k}(\cdot). This implementation has two important drawbacks, which render it impractical in a federated learning setting. First, it requires full agent participation at every iteration, by means of computation and communication of ∇Jk​(wi−1)∇subscript𝐽𝑘subscript𝑤𝑖1\nabla J_{k}(w_{i-1}) with a central aggregator. In federated learning applications, where agents may or may not be able to participate in the update at any given iteration, this can cause bottlenecks. Second, evaluation of the exact gradient ∇Jk​(wi−1)∇subscript𝐽𝑘subscript𝑤𝑖1\nabla J_{k}(w_{i-1}) may be infeasible or costly, since it depends on the full distribution of \xksubscript\x𝑘\x_{k} through its expectation in (1).

1.1 Related Works

Distributed algorithms for solving aggregate optimization problems similar to (2) can be broadly classified into those that involve communication with a centralized parameter server [11, 12, 13, 14], and those that operate in a fully decentralized manner through peer-to-peer interactions [15, 16, 17, 18, 19]. Federated Averaging (FedAvg) was introduced in [20], and has sparked a number of studies and extensions, including FedDane [21], FedProx [22], hierarchical FedAvg [23], and dynamic FedAvg [24]. While the pursuit of an optimal average model as in (2) is most common, multi-task variations have been introduced as well, both in a federated [25] and decentralized settings [26].

Most prior works on federated learning and the FedAvg algorithm focus on convex risk functions [13, 14, 24], or establish first-order stationarity in non-convex environments [27, 28, 29, 21, 22, 23]. On the other hand, saddle points, which are first-order stationary, have been identified as bottlenecks in many learning applications, including deep learning [2]. This contrast to the empirical success of deep learning has motivated a number of recent works to consider the ability of gradient descent algorithms to escape saddle-points and find “good” local minima, both in centralized [30, 4, 31, 5, 6, 7, 8] and decentralized settings [32, 33, 9, 10]. The broad take-away from these works is that perturbations, either to the initialization or gradient updates, play a key role in pushing iterates away from strict-saddle points and toward local minimizers. In this work, we extend these results to the federated learning setting, where agents may take an arbitrary number of local steps before communicating with the central parameter server.

2 Algorithm Formulation

2.1 The Federated Averaging Scheme

The need for full and exact agent participation in evaluating (3) in a federated setting is addressed in the stochastic federated averaging (FedAvg) framework [20]. To this end, the parameter server selects at iteration i𝑖i a subset of L𝐿L agents, collected in the set 𝒩isubscript𝒩𝑖\mathcal{N}_{i}. We introduce a random indicator variable 𝟙k,isubscript1𝑘𝑖\mathds{1}_{k,i}, which indicates whether agent k𝑘k participates at time i𝑖i, i.e., 𝟙k,i=1⟺k∈𝒩i⟺subscript1𝑘𝑖1𝑘subscript𝒩𝑖\mathds{1}_{k,i}=1\Longleftrightarrow k\in\mathcal{N}_{i}, and 00 otherwise. We assume for simplicity that agents are sampled uniformly at random, resulting in:

Pr​{𝟙k,i=1}=\E​{𝟙k,i}=LKPrsubscript1𝑘𝑖1\Esubscript1𝑘𝑖𝐿𝐾\mathrm{Pr}\left\{\mathds{1}_{k,i}=1\right\}=\E\left\{\mathds{1}_{k,i}\right\}=\frac{L}{K} (4)

Then, the parameter server provides participating agents with the current aggregate model \wi−1subscript\w𝑖1\w_{i-1}. They use the model to initialize their local iterate to \wk,0=\wi−1subscript\w𝑘0subscript\w𝑖1\w_{k,0}=\w_{i-1} and then perform Eksubscript𝐸𝑘E_{k} local stochastic update steps for e=1,…,Ek𝑒1…subscript𝐸𝑘e=1,\ldots,E_{k}:

\wk,e=\wk,e−1−μ​K​𝟙k,i​pkEk​∇J^ke​(\wk,e−1)subscript\w𝑘𝑒subscript\w𝑘𝑒1𝜇𝐾subscript1𝑘𝑖subscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝐸𝑘superscriptsubscript^∇𝐽𝑘𝑒subscript\w𝑘𝑒1\w_{k,e}=\w_{k,e-1}-\mu K\mathds{1}_{k,i}\frac{p_{k}}{E_{k}}\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\w_{k,e-1}) (5)

Here, ∇J^ke​(\wk,e−1)superscriptsubscript^∇𝐽𝑘𝑒subscript\w𝑘𝑒1\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\w_{k,e-1}) denotes a generic stochastic approximation of the gradient ∇Jk​(\wk,e−1)∇subscript𝐽𝑘subscript\w𝑘𝑒1\nabla J_{k}(\w_{k,e-1}). Using realizations for the random variable \xksubscript\x𝑘\x_{k}, it is common to construct ∇J^ke​(\wk,e−1)≜∇Q​(\wk,e−1,\xk,e)≜superscriptsubscript^∇𝐽𝑘𝑒subscript\w𝑘𝑒1∇𝑄subscript\w𝑘𝑒1subscript\x𝑘𝑒\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\w_{k,e-1})\triangleq\nabla Q(\w_{k,e-1},\x_{k,e}), resulting in stochastic gradient descent — we will discuss other constructions and their advantages in Section 2.2 below. The updated models are then fused by the central aggregator according to:

\wi=1L​∑k=1K𝟙k,i​\wk,Eksubscript\w𝑖1𝐿superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript1𝑘𝑖subscript\w𝑘subscript𝐸𝑘\w_{i}=\frac{1}{L}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathds{1}_{k,i}\w_{k,E_{k}} (6)

2.2 A General Stochastic Approximation Framework

We now present a number of choices for the stochastic gradient approximation ∇J^ke​(\wk,e−1)superscriptsubscript^∇𝐽𝑘𝑒subscript\w𝑘𝑒1\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\w_{k,e-1}) to illustrate the generality of (5). {example}[Mini-Batch SGD] Given a collection of Bksubscript𝐵𝑘B_{k} samples {\xk,e,b}b=1Bksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript\x𝑘𝑒𝑏𝑏1subscript𝐵𝑘\left\{\x_{k,e,b}\right\}_{b=1}^{B_{k}}, constructing:

∇J^ke​(\wk,e−1)=1Bk​∑b=1Bk∇Q​(\wk,e−1,\xk,e,b)superscriptsubscript^∇𝐽𝑘𝑒subscript\w𝑘𝑒11subscript𝐵𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑏1subscript𝐵𝑘∇𝑄subscript\w𝑘𝑒1subscript\x𝑘𝑒𝑏\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\w_{k,e-1})=\frac{1}{B_{k}}\sum_{b=1}^{B_{k}}\nabla Q(\w_{k,e-1},\x_{k,e,b}) (7)

yields mini-batch stochastic gradient descent, or simply stochastic gradient descent when Bk=1subscript𝐵𝑘1B_{k}=1.\qed {example}[Perturbed SGD] It has been observed, both empirically and analytically, that adding additional perturbations to the stochastic gradient update can improve the performance of the gradient descent algorithm in non-convex settings [6]. In the presence of privacy concerns, perturbations to update directions can also be added in order to ensure differential privacy [34]. This corresponds to constructing:

∇J^ke​(\wk,e−1)=∇Q​(\wk,e−1,\xk,e)+𝒗k,esuperscriptsubscript^∇𝐽𝑘𝑒subscript\w𝑘𝑒1∇𝑄subscript\w𝑘𝑒1subscript\x𝑘𝑒subscript𝒗𝑘𝑒\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\w_{k,e-1})=\nabla Q(\w_{k,e-1},\x_{k,e})+\boldsymbol{v}_{k,e} (8)

where 𝒗k,esubscript𝒗𝑘𝑒\boldsymbol{v}_{k,e} denotes i.i.d. perturbation noise with zero mean, following for example a Gaussian or Laplacian distribution.\qed {example}[Straggling Agents] Consider a setting where agents may be unreliable, in the sense that, despite being chosen by the parameter server to participate at iteration i𝑖i, they may fail to return a locally updated model \wk,Eksubscript\w𝑘subscript𝐸𝑘\w_{k,E_{k}} by the time the server needs to re-aggregate models in (6). Such a setting can be modeled via:

∇J^ke​(\wk,e−1)={1δk​∇Q​(\wk,e−1,\xk,e)with​prob.δk,0otherwise.superscriptsubscript^∇𝐽𝑘𝑒subscript\w𝑘𝑒1cases1subscript𝛿𝑘∇𝑄subscript\w𝑘𝑒1subscript\x𝑘𝑒formulae-sequencewithprobsubscript𝛿𝑘0otherwise\displaystyle\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\w_{k,e-1})=\begin{cases}\frac{1}{\delta_{k}}\nabla Q(\w_{k,e-1},\x_{k,e})\ &\mathrm{with}\ \mathrm{prob.}\ \delta_{k},\\ 0\ &\mathrm{otherwise.}\end{cases} (9)

Here, the scaling factor 1δk1subscript𝛿𝑘\frac{1}{\delta_{k}} has been added to ensure unbiased gradient approximations, by allowing agents who participate less frequently to take larger steps. Alternative stochastic models for asynchronous behavior are possible as well [35].\qed It can be readily verified, that all three constructions in Examples 2.2–8 are unbiased approximations of the true gradient ∇Jk​(\wk,e−1)∇subscript𝐽𝑘subscript\w𝑘𝑒1\nabla J_{k}(\w_{k,e-1}), i.e.:

\E​{∇J^ke​(\wk,e−1)|\wk,e−1}=∇Jk​(\wk,e−1)\Econditional-setsuperscriptsubscript^∇𝐽𝑘𝑒subscript\w𝑘𝑒1subscript\w𝑘𝑒1∇subscript𝐽𝑘subscript\w𝑘𝑒1\E\left\{\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\w_{k,e-1})|\w_{k,e-1}\right\}=\nabla J_{k}(\w_{k,e-1}) (10)

Nevertheless, the stochastic nature of the approximation induces a gradient noise into the evolution of the algorithm, which we denote by:

\sk,e​(\wk,e−1)≜∇J^ke​(\wk,e−1)−∇Jk​(\wk,e−1)≜subscript\s𝑘𝑒subscript\w𝑘𝑒1superscriptsubscript^∇𝐽𝑘𝑒subscript\w𝑘𝑒1∇subscript𝐽𝑘subscript\w𝑘𝑒1\s_{k,e}(\w_{k,e-1})\triangleq\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\w_{k,e-1})-\nabla J_{k}(\w_{k,e-1}) (11)

We impose the following general conditions on the stochastic gradient noise process, and hence the construction of the stochastic gradient approximation itself. {assumption}[Gradient Noise Process] The gradient noise process (11) satisfies:

\E​{\sk,e​(\wk,e−1)|\wk,e−1}\Econditional-setsubscript\s𝑘𝑒subscript\w𝑘𝑒1subscript\w𝑘𝑒1\displaystyle\E\{\s_{k,e}(\w_{k,e-1})|\w_{k,e-1}\} =0absent0\displaystyle=0 (12)
\E​{‖\sk,e​(\wk,e−1)‖4|\wk,e−1}\Econditionalsuperscriptnormsubscript\s𝑘𝑒subscript\w𝑘𝑒14subscript\w𝑘𝑒1\displaystyle\E\{\|\s_{k,e}(\w_{k,e-1})\|^{4}|\w_{k,e-1}\} ≤βk4​‖∇Jk​(\wk,e−1)‖4+σk4absentsuperscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘4superscriptnorm∇subscript𝐽𝑘subscript\w𝑘𝑒14superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘4\displaystyle\leq\beta_{k}^{4}\|\nabla J_{k}(\w_{k,e-1})\|^{4}+\sigma_{k}^{4} (13)

for some βk4,σk4≥0superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘4superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘40\beta_{k}^{4},\sigma_{k}^{4}\geq 0. It is assumed that the gradient noise process is mutually independent over space and time, after conditioning on the current iterate:

𝔼​{\sk1,e1​(\w)​\sk2,e2​(\w)𝖳|\w}=𝔼conditional-setsubscript\ssubscript𝑘1subscript𝑒1\wsubscript\ssubscript𝑘2subscript𝑒2superscript\w𝖳\wabsent\displaystyle\mathds{E}\left\{\s_{k_{1},e_{1}}(\w)\s_{k_{2},e_{2}}(\w)^{\mathsf{T}}|\w\right\}=  0∀k1≠k2​or​e1≠e2 0for-allsubscript𝑘1subscript𝑘2orsubscript𝑒1subscript𝑒2\displaystyle\>0\ \ \ \forall\ k_{1}\neq k_{2}\ \mathrm{or}\ e_{1}\neq e_{2} (14)

and the gradient noise covariance:

Rs,k​(\wk,e−1)≜𝔼​{\sk,e​(\wk,e−1)​\sk,e​(\wk,e−1)𝖳|\wk,e−1}≜subscript𝑅𝑠𝑘subscript\w𝑘𝑒1𝔼conditional-setsubscript\s𝑘𝑒subscript\w𝑘𝑒1subscript\s𝑘𝑒superscriptsubscript\w𝑘𝑒1𝖳subscript\w𝑘𝑒1R_{s,k}(\w_{k,e-1})\triangleq\mathds{E}\left\{\s_{k,e}(\w_{k,e-1})\s_{k,e}(\w_{k,e-1})^{\mathsf{T}}|\w_{k,e-1}\right\} (15)

is smooth:

‖Rs,k​(x)−Rs,k​(y)‖≤βR​‖x−y‖γnormsubscript𝑅𝑠𝑘𝑥subscript𝑅𝑠𝑘𝑦subscript𝛽𝑅superscriptnorm𝑥𝑦𝛾\|R_{s,k}(x)-R_{s,k}(y)\|\leq\beta_{R}{\|x-y\|}^{\gamma} (16)

for some βRsubscript𝛽𝑅\beta_{R} and 0<γ≤40𝛾40<\gamma\leq 4, and there is a gradient noise component (in the aggregate) in every direction:

Rs,k​(x)≥σℓ2​I,∀xsubscript𝑅𝑠𝑘𝑥superscriptsubscript𝜎ℓ2𝐼for-all𝑥R_{s,k}(x)\geq\sigma_{\ell}^{2}I,\ \ \ \forall\ x (17)
\qed

Relation (12) ensures that the stochastic gradient approximation is unbiased, while (13) imposes a relative bound on the fourth-order moment [17]. In light of Jensen’s inequality, it is stronger than imposing a bound on the gradient noise variance, but will allow us to more granularly study the impact of the gradient noise around saddle-points; on the other hand, it is weaker than the more common conditions of bounded noise with probability one, or a sub-Gaussian condition [6, 7]. Relation (16) ensures that the distribution of the stochastic gradient noise process is locally smooth, allowing us to formulate an accurate short-term model around saddle-points [8]. It has previously been utilized to analyze in detail the steady-state behavior of stochastic gradient algorithms in convex environments [17]. The persistent noise condition (17) will allow recursions to efficiently escape saddle-points by relying on the aggregate effect of the noise coupled with the local instability of saddle-points. It can be relaxed to only require a noise component to be present in the subspace of local descent directions [5, 8]. Since (17) can always be ensured by adding a small amount of isotropic perturbations to the stochastic gradient update as in (8), it will be sufficient, for simplicity, to impose (17) in this work.

3 Performance Analysis

3.1 A Perturbed Centralized Gradient Recursion

By iterating (5), we find for the final local update \wk,Eksubscript\w𝑘subscript𝐸𝑘\w_{k,E_{k}} sent back to the parameter server:

\wk,Ek=\wi−1−μ​K​𝟙k,i​pkEk​∑e=1Ek∇J^ke​(\wk,e−1)subscript\w𝑘subscript𝐸𝑘subscript\w𝑖1𝜇𝐾subscript1𝑘𝑖subscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝐸𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑒1subscript𝐸𝑘superscriptsubscript^∇𝐽𝑘𝑒subscript\w𝑘𝑒1\w_{k,E_{k}}=\w_{i-1}-\mu K\mathds{1}_{k,i}\frac{p_{k}}{E_{k}}\sum_{e=1}^{E_{k}}\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\w_{k,e-1}) (18)

and after aggregation in (6):

\wi=\wi−1−μ​KL​∑k=1K𝟙k,i​pkEk​∑e=1Ek∇J^ke​(\wk,e−1)subscript\w𝑖subscript\w𝑖1𝜇𝐾𝐿superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript1𝑘𝑖subscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝐸𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑒1subscript𝐸𝑘superscriptsubscript^∇𝐽𝑘𝑒subscript\w𝑘𝑒1\displaystyle\w_{i}=\w_{i-1}-\mu\frac{K}{L}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathds{1}_{k,i}\frac{p_{k}}{E_{k}}\sum_{e=1}^{E_{k}}\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\w_{k,e-1}) (19)

We can reformulate this recursion to resemble the deterministic recursion (3) as:

\wi=\wi−1−μ​∑k=1Kpk​∇Jk​(\wi−1)−μ​𝒔i−μ​𝒅isubscript\w𝑖subscript\w𝑖1𝜇superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑝𝑘∇subscript𝐽𝑘subscript\w𝑖1𝜇subscript𝒔𝑖𝜇subscript𝒅𝑖\w_{i}=\w_{i-1}-\mu\sum_{k=1}^{K}p_{k}\nabla J_{k}(\w_{i-1})-\mu\boldsymbol{s}_{i}-\mu\boldsymbol{d}_{i} (20)

where 𝒔isubscript𝒔𝑖\boldsymbol{s}_{i} and 𝒅isubscript𝒅𝑖\boldsymbol{d}_{i} are perturbation terms:

\si≜≜subscript\s𝑖absent\displaystyle\s_{i}\triangleq KL​∑k=1K𝟙k,i​pkEk​∑e=1Ek∇J^ke​(\wi−1)−∇J​(\wi−1)𝐾𝐿superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript1𝑘𝑖subscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝐸𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑒1subscript𝐸𝑘superscriptsubscript^∇𝐽𝑘𝑒subscript\w𝑖1∇𝐽subscript\w𝑖1\displaystyle\>\frac{K}{L}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathds{1}_{k,i}\frac{p_{k}}{E_{k}}\sum_{e=1}^{E_{k}}\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\w_{i-1})-\nabla J(\w_{i-1}) (21)
𝒅i≜≜subscript𝒅𝑖absent\displaystyle\boldsymbol{d}_{i}\triangleq KL​∑k=1K𝟙k,i​pkEk​∑e=1Ek(∇J^ke​(\wk,e−1)−∇J^ke​(\wi−1))𝐾𝐿superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript1𝑘𝑖subscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝐸𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑒1subscript𝐸𝑘superscriptsubscript^∇𝐽𝑘𝑒subscript\w𝑘𝑒1superscriptsubscript^∇𝐽𝑘𝑒subscript\w𝑖1\displaystyle\>\frac{K}{L}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathds{1}_{k,i}\frac{p_{k}}{E_{k}}\sum_{e=1}^{E_{k}}\left(\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\w_{k,e-1})-\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\w_{i-1})\right) (22)

Comparing (20) with (3), we observe that the FedAvg implementation can be viewed as a perturbed gradient descent recursion. Perturbations have recently been shown to be instrumental in allowing local descent algorithms to escape from saddle-points and converge to local minima of non-convex loss functions. However, those studies are generally limited to assuming unbiased perturbations. In contrast, employing (5) with Ek>1subscript𝐸𝑘1E_{k}>1 results in biased gradient perturbations resulting from the term 𝒅isubscript𝒅𝑖\boldsymbol{d}_{i}, rendering current analyses inapplicable. In this work, we generalize recent results on the second-order guarantees of stochastic gradient algorithms [8] to allow for biased gradient perturbations, and recover second-order guarantees for the FedAvg algorithm for heterogeneous agents. We describe and discuss the dependence of these guarantees on the various parameters of the architecture, such as agent participation rate, levels heterogeneity, asynchrony, and computational capabilities.

We introduce the following smoothness conditions to ensure that the impact of the perturbations (21)–(22) is limited. {assumption}[Smoothness] The local costs Jk​(w)subscript𝐽𝑘𝑤J_{k}(w) are assumed to be smooth:

‖∇Jk​(x)−∇Jk​(y)‖norm∇subscript𝐽𝑘𝑥∇subscript𝐽𝑘𝑦\displaystyle\left\|\nabla J_{k}(x)-\nabla J_{k}(y)\right\| ≤δ​‖x−y‖absent𝛿norm𝑥𝑦\displaystyle\leq\delta\left\|x-y\right\| (23)
‖∇2Jk​(x)−∇2Jk​(y)‖normsuperscript∇2subscript𝐽𝑘𝑥superscript∇2subscript𝐽𝑘𝑦\displaystyle\left\|\nabla^{2}J_{k}(x)-\nabla^{2}J_{k}(y)\right\| ≤ρ​‖x−y‖absent𝜌norm𝑥𝑦\displaystyle\leq\rho\left\|x-y\right\| (24)

Heterogeneity between agents is quantified by their gradient disagreement:

‖∇Jk​(x)−∇Jℓ​(x)‖≤Gnorm∇subscript𝐽𝑘𝑥∇subscript𝐽ℓ𝑥𝐺\|\nabla J_{k}(x)-\nabla J_{\ell}(x)\|\leq G (25)

Furthermore, the costs themselves are assumed to be Lipschitz, implying uniformly bounded gradient:

‖∇Jk​(x)‖≤Unorm∇subscript𝐽𝑘𝑥𝑈\|\nabla J_{k}(x)\|\leq U (26)

and the stochastic approximations of the gradient are Lipschitz in the mean-fourth sense:

\E​{‖∇J^ke​(\x)−∇J^ke​(\y)‖4|\x,\y}≤δ^4​‖\x−\y‖4\Econditionalsuperscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript^∇𝐽𝑘𝑒\xsuperscriptsubscript^∇𝐽𝑘𝑒\y4\x\ysuperscript^𝛿4superscriptnorm\x\y4\E\left\{{\left\|\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\x)-\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\y)\right\|}^{4}|\x,\y\right\}\leq\hat{\delta}^{4}\left\|\x-\y\right\|^{4} (27)
\qed

Appendix A.

3.3 Second-Order Guarantees

Examination of the bounds (28)–(30) reveals that the aggregate zero-mean component \sisubscript\s𝑖\s_{i} arising from the use of stochastic gradient approximations continues to be bounded in a manner similar to the local approximations (13), where the aggregate constant bounds are determined by the quality of local approximations {βk4,σk4}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘4superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘4𝑘1𝐾\{\beta_{k}^{4},\sigma_{k}^{4}\}_{k=1}^{K}, the participation rate LK𝐿𝐾\frac{L}{K}, the weights {pk}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑘1𝐾\{p_{k}\}_{k=1}^{K}, the level of heterogeneity G𝐺G, and number of local updates taken Eksubscript𝐸𝑘E_{k}. The bias 𝒅isubscript𝒅𝑖\boldsymbol{d}_{i} induced by employing multiple local updates, on the other hand, does not have zero-mean. The bound on its fourth-order moment (30), however, is proportional to μ4superscript𝜇4\mu^{4}, causing its effect to be small for small step-sizes when compared to \sisubscript\s𝑖\s_{i}, which is independent in μ𝜇\mu. The fact that 𝒅isubscript𝒅𝑖\boldsymbol{d}_{i} is biased renders traditional second-order analysis of stochastic gradient algorithms [4, 5, 6, 1, 8] inapplicable to this setting, while the fact that its fourth-order moment is small compared to \sisubscript\s𝑖\s_{i} makes it possible to extend the arguments of [1, 8]. {theorem} Suppose the aggregate loss J​(w)𝐽𝑤J(w) is bounded from below by J​(w)≥Jo𝐽𝑤superscript𝐽𝑜J(w)\geq J^{o}. Then, with probability 1−2​π12𝜋1-2\pi:

‖∇J​(\wio)‖2≤μ​δ​σ¯21−2​μ​δ​(1+β¯2)​(1+1π)+O​(μ2)superscriptnorm∇𝐽subscript\wsuperscript𝑖𝑜2𝜇𝛿superscript¯𝜎212𝜇𝛿1superscript¯𝛽211𝜋𝑂superscript𝜇2\|\nabla J(\w_{i^{o}})\|^{2}\leq\mu\frac{\delta\overline{\sigma}^{2}}{1-2\mu\delta(1+\overline{\beta}^{2})}\left(1+\frac{1}{\pi}\right)+O(\mu^{2}) (37)

and λmin​(∇2J​(\wio))≥−τsubscript𝜆superscript∇2𝐽subscript\wsuperscript𝑖𝑜𝜏\lambda_{\min}\left(\nabla^{2}J(\w_{i^{o}})\right)\geq-\tau in at most iosuperscript𝑖𝑜i^{o} iterations, where

io≤2​(J​(w0)−Jo)μ2​δ​σ¯2​issuperscript𝑖𝑜2𝐽subscript𝑤0superscript𝐽𝑜superscript𝜇2𝛿superscript¯𝜎2superscript𝑖𝑠\displaystyle i^{o}\leq\frac{2\left(J(w_{0})-J^{o}\right)}{\mu^{2}\delta\overline{\sigma}^{2}}i^{s} (38)

and issuperscript𝑖𝑠i^{s} denotes the saddle-point escape time:

is=log⁡(2​M​σ¯2σ¯ℓ2+1+O​(μ))log​(1+2​μ​τ)superscript𝑖𝑠2𝑀superscript¯𝜎2superscriptsubscript¯𝜎ℓ21𝑂𝜇log12𝜇𝜏\displaystyle i^{s}=\frac{\log\left(2M\frac{{\overline{\sigma}^{2}}}{{\overline{\sigma}_{\ell}^{2}}}+1+O(\mu)\right)}{\mathrm{log}\left(1+2\mu\tau\right)} (39)
{proof}

The argument is an adjustment of [8] by bounding away the effect of 𝒅isubscript𝒅𝑖\boldsymbol{d}_{i}. Details omitted due to space limitations. This result ensures that, with probability 1−2​π12𝜋1-2\pi, the FedAvg algorithm will return a second-order stationary point with ‖∇J​(\wio)‖2≤O​(μ)superscriptnorm∇𝐽subscript\wsuperscript𝑖𝑜2𝑂𝜇\|\nabla J(\w_{i^{o}})\|^{2}\leq O(\mu) and λmin​(∇2J​(\wio))≥−τsubscript𝜆superscript∇2𝐽subscript\wsuperscript𝑖𝑜𝜏\lambda_{\min}\left(\nabla^{2}J(\w_{i^{o}})\right)\geq-\tau in at most iosuperscript𝑖𝑜i^{o} iterations, where iosuperscript𝑖𝑜i^{o} scales polynomially with all problem parameters. Every second-order stationary point, in light of ‖∇J​(\wio)‖2≤O​(μ)superscriptnorm∇𝐽subscript\wsuperscript𝑖𝑜2𝑂𝜇\|\nabla J(\w_{i^{o}})\|^{2}\leq O(\mu) is also first-order stationary, but the additional condition λmin​(∇2J​(\wio))≥−τsubscript𝜆superscript∇2𝐽subscript\wsuperscript𝑖𝑜𝜏\lambda_{\min}\left(\nabla^{2}J(\w_{i^{o}})\right)\geq-\tau allows for the exclusion of strict saddle-points by choosing τ𝜏\tau sufficiently small.

4 Numerical Results

We illustrate the ability of the FedAvg algorithm to escape saddle-points for:

Q​(w1,W2;𝜸,𝒉)≜log⁡(1+e−𝜸​w1\T​W2​𝒉)≜𝑄subscript𝑤1subscript𝑊2𝜸𝒉1superscript𝑒𝜸superscriptsubscript𝑤1\Tsubscript𝑊2𝒉\displaystyle\>Q(w_{1},W_{2};\boldsymbol{\gamma},\boldsymbol{h})\triangleq\log\left(1+e^{-\boldsymbol{\gamma}w_{1}^{\T}W_{2}\boldsymbol{h}}\right) (40)
J​(w1,W2)≜\E​Q​(w1,W2;𝜸,𝒉)+ρ2​‖w1‖2+ρ2​‖W2‖2≜𝐽subscript𝑤1subscript𝑊2\E𝑄subscript𝑤1subscript𝑊2𝜸𝒉𝜌2superscriptnormsubscript𝑤12𝜌2superscriptnormsubscript𝑊22\displaystyle\>J(w_{1},W_{2})\triangleq\E Q(w_{1},W_{2};\boldsymbol{\gamma},\boldsymbol{h})+\frac{\rho}{2}\|w_{1}\|^{2}+\frac{\rho}{2}\|W_{2}\|^{2} (41)

This loss arises when training a neural network with a single, linear hidden layer to predict the class label 𝜸𝜸\boldsymbol{\gamma} from 𝒉𝒉\boldsymbol{h} using cross-entropy, and exhibits a strict saddle-point at w1=W2=0subscript𝑤1subscript𝑊20w_{1}=W_{2}=0, making it suitable as a simplified benchmark — see [9] for a discussion and motivation. For a total of K=100𝐾100K=100 agents, we vary the rate of participation from L=1𝐿1L=1 to L=100𝐿100L=100. Agents are chosen uniformly, and participating agents perform E=10𝐸10E=10 local updates constructed as a combination of Examples 7 and 8, namely:

∇J^ke​(\wk,e−1)=1δk​(∇Q​(\wk,e−1,\xk,e)−ρ​\wk,e−1)superscriptsubscript^∇𝐽𝑘𝑒subscript\w𝑘𝑒11subscript𝛿𝑘∇𝑄subscript\w𝑘𝑒1subscript\x𝑘𝑒𝜌subscript\w𝑘𝑒1\displaystyle\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\w_{k,e-1})=\frac{1}{\delta_{k}}\left(\nabla Q(\w_{k,e-1},\x_{k,e})-\rho\w_{k,e-1}\right) (42)

with probability pk=0.5subscript𝑝𝑘0.5p_{k}=0.5, and ∇J^ke​(\wk,e−1)=0superscriptsubscript^∇𝐽𝑘𝑒subscript\w𝑘𝑒10\widehat{\nabla J}_{k}^{e}(\w_{k,e-1})=0 otherwise. Evolution of iterates and the gradient norm are shown in Figures 1 and 2 respectively.

5 Conclusion

In this work, we considered a highly heterogeneous and asynchronous variant of the Federated Averaging (FedAvg) algorithm, where agents may be using varying, potentially unreliable, stochastic gradient approximations with varying quality, and take a different number Eksubscript𝐸𝑘E_{k} of local update steps, and established convergence to second-order stationary points. Despite high levels of heterogeneity and asynchrony, the algorithm continues to escape saddle-points and return second-order stationary points in polynomial time, shedding light on the success of deep learning, which is frequently employed in federated learning settings.

Appendix A Proof of Lemma 3.2

We begin by establishing that \sisubscript\s𝑖\s_{i} has conditional zero-mean:
